importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Tel Aviv soccer derby cancellation, marking a significant incident of public disorder in Israel.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe indicates when the incident occurred and when the article was published, providing context for real-time public reaction and media coverage.

keyTakeAways: The Tel Aviv soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi was canceled due to violent riots and public disorder involving fans and police.
Police reported 12 civilians and 3 officers injured, with 9 arrests and 16 people detained for questioning.
Footage showed pyrotechnics and smoke grenades being thrown from the stands prior to kickoff, prompting the cancellation due to 'endangerment of human life'.
Hapoel criticized the police response, accusing them of preparing for a 'war' instead of a sporting event and claiming the decision to cancel was disproportionate.

The incident echoes previous security concerns involving Maccabi fans, including a ban in England for a Europa League game against Aston Villa and violent scenes during a match in Amsterdam against Ajax.
UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the English ban on Maccabi fans, stating it was 'wrong' and emphasized the need for all fans to enjoy football without fear.
Downing Street acknowledged the need for understanding and cooperation between UK and Israeli police forces in response to the Tel Aviv incident.

namedEntities.name: Tel Aviv
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location of the soccer derby and the site of the violent riots that led to the match cancellation.

namedEntities.name: Hapoel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A professional soccer club based in Tel Aviv, Israel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the two rival teams in the Tel Aviv derby, whose fans were involved in the riot and who criticized the police response.

namedEntities.name: Maccabi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A professional soccer club based in Tel Aviv, Israel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The other rival team in the Tel Aviv derby, whose fans were also involved in the unrest and who did not publicly comment on the incident.

namedEntities.name: Bloomfield Stadium
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shared stadium in Tel Aviv used by both Hapoel and Maccabi
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The venue where the derby was scheduled to be played, which became the site of public disorder and rioting.

namedEntities.name: Israel Police
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The national law enforcement agency of Israel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The authorities who intervened, canceled the match, and reported injuries and arrests during the unrest.

namedEntities.name: Aston Villa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A professional football club in England
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The English club against which Maccabi fans were banned from attending a Europa League match due to security concerns.

namedEntities.name: West Midlands Police
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The police force in England responsible for the ban on Maccabi fans
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The local police agency that issued the ban on Maccabi fans in England, which is connected to broader security concerns in Europe.

namedEntities.name: Ajax (Dutch football club)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A professional football club in the Netherlands
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dutch team against which Maccabi fans were involved in violent incidents in Amsterdam last year.

namedEntities.name: Keir Starmer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Prime Minister of the United Kingdom
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The UK leader who criticized the ban on Maccabi fans in England and expressed concern over fan security and discrimination.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source of the article, providing international coverage of the incident in Israel and its implications in the UK context.

namedEntities.name: Europa League
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The tournament in which Maccabi fans were banned from attending a match against Aston Villa due to security concerns.

namedEntities.name: Downing Street
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The official residence of the UK Prime Minister
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source of the official UK government statement regarding the ban on Maccabi fans and the incident in Tel Aviv.

namedEntities.name: UK Football Policing Unit
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A unit within the UK police responsible for football-related security
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The unit engaging with Israeli police to understand the events in Tel Aviv and address cross-border security concerns.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Tel Aviv soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi was canceled due to violent riots and public disorder at Bloomfield Stadium, where fans clashed with police and threw pyrotechnics and smoke grenades. The Israel Police reported 12 civilians and three officers injured, with nine arrests and 16 people detained. Hapoel criticized the police decision, accusing them of overreacting and taking a militarized approach. This incident follows prior security concerns, including a ban on Maccabi fans in England due to their history of violent behavior, which drew criticism from UK leaders like Prime Minister Keir Starmer, who emphasized the need for inclusivity and safety in sports. The UK government has now initiated dialogue with Israeli authorities to understand the Tel Aviv events and address shared concerns about fan safety and cross-border policing.
title: Tel Aviv soccer derby canceled by police due to 'violent riots'
